step_by_step.explanation: The Phillips Curve shows an inverse relationship between the rate of inflation and the rate of unemployment in the short run.

problems.final_answer: Phillips Curve: inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment (short run).

problems.problem: Differentiate short-run Phillips Curve (SRPC) and long-run Phillips Curve (LRPC).

step_by_step.explanation: SRPC shows a trade-off between inflation and unemployment in the short run.
LRPC is vertical at the natural rate of unemployment; no long-term trade-off exists between inflation and unemployment.

problems.final_answer: SRPC: short-run trade-off; LRPC: vertical, no long-term trade-off.

problems.problem: Explain the natural rate of unemployment.

step_by_step.explanation: The natural rate of unemployment is the level of unemployment consistent with stable inflation; includes frictional and structural unemployment.

problems.final_answer: Natural rate of unemployment: unemployment consistent with stable inflation (frictional + structural).

problems.problem: Explain demand-pull inflation using the Phillips Curve.

step_by_step.explanation: An increase in aggregate demand lowers unemployment temporarily, increasing inflation along the SRPC.

problems.final_answer: Demand-pull inflation: ↑ AD → ↓ unemployment → ↑ inflation (short run).

problems.problem: Explain cost-push inflation using the Phillips Curve.

step_by_step.explanation: A decrease in aggregate supply raises prices and unemployment, shifting the SRPC upward.

problems.final_answer: Cost-push inflation: ↓ AS → ↑ prices & unemployment → SRPC shifts up.

step_by_step.explanation: Incorporates inflation expectations; if expected inflation rises, actual inflation rises for same unemployment, shifting SRPC upward.

problems.final_answer: Expectations-augmented PC: ↑ expected inflation → SRPC shifts up; trade-off temporary.

problems.problem: Explain the role of stabilization policy.

step_by_step.explanation: Stabilization policy uses fiscal or monetary policy to reduce fluctuations in output, unemployment, and inflation.

problems.final_answer: Stabilization policy: fiscal/monetary actions to reduce economic fluctuations.

problems.problem: Explain the short-run trade-off between unemployment and inflation.

step_by_step.explanation: In the short run, policies that increase AD can reduce unemployment but increase inflation; reducing AD lowers inflation but increases unemployment.

problems.final_answer: Short-run trade-off: ↑ AD → ↓ unemployment, ↑ inflation; ↓ AD → ↑ unemployment, ↓ inflation.

problems.problem: Explain why the long-run Phillips Curve is vertical.

step_by_step.explanation: In the long run, inflation expectations adjust, and unemployment returns to its natural rate, so there is no trade-off between inflation and unemployment.

problems.final_answer: LRPC vertical: expectations adjust, unemployment = natural rate, no long-run trade-off.

problems.problem: Explain the concept of stagflation using the Phillips Curve.

step_by_step.explanation: Stagflation occurs when high inflation and high unemployment exist simultaneously, typically due to negative supply shocks, shown as an upward shift in SRPC.

problems.final_answer: Stagflation: ↑ inflation + ↑ unemployment → SRPC shifts up due to negative supply shock.
